citeinfo.title: National Atlas of the United States

descript.abstract: This point dataset represents streams gages in the Conterminous United States. All feature classes are vertically integrated with each other and with 1:1,000,000-scale transportation and boundary data sets.
descript.purpose: This dataset is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.
descript.supplinf: This data was originally stored in a geodatabase. All feature classes are vertically integrated with each other and with 1:1,000,000-scale transportation and boundary data sets.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S Geological Survey, National Atlas of the United States

cntinfo.cntinst: For questions about this geodatabase or metadata, please contact the National Atlas using the information above, or through the U.S. Geological Survey contact page at http://www.usgs.gov/ask/. For distribution questions, please see the Distribution Information elsewhere in this metadata.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdefs: Tufts University. Geographic Information Systems Center

edom.edomvds: Tufts University. Geographic Information Systems Center

edom.edomvd: Estuary: A coastal inlet of the sea or ocean; especially the mouth of a river, where tide normally mixes with stream water.

Diversion: A site where water is withdrawn or diverted from a surface-water body (e.g. the point where the upstream end of a canal intesects with a stream, or point where water is withdrawn from a reservoir). Includes sites where water is pumped for use elsewhere.

Lake, reservoir, impoundment: An inland body of standing fresh or saline water that is generally too deep to permit submerged aquatic vegetation to take root across the entire body. This type includes an expanded part of a river, a reservoir behind a dam, and a natural or excavated depression containing a water body without surface-water inlet and/or outlet
Spring: A location at which the water table intersects the land surface, resulting in a natural flow of groundwater to the surface. Springs may be perennial, intermiitent, or ephemeral

Stream: A body of running water moving under gravity flow in a defined channel. The channel may be entirely natural, or altered by engineering practices through straightening, dredging, and /or lining. An entirely artificial channel should be qualified with the 'canal' or 'ditch' secondary site type.
Canal: An artificial watercourse designed for navigation, drainage, or irrigation by connecting two or more bodies of water; it is larger than a ditch.
Ditch: An excavation artificially dug into the ground, either lined or unlined, for conveying water for drainage or irrigation; it is smaller than a canal.

Tidal Stream: A stream reach where the flow is influenced by the tide, but where the water chemisty is not normally influenced. A site where ocean water typically mixes with stream water should be coded as an estuary.

Wetland: Land where saturation with water is the dominant factor determining the nature of soil development and the types of plant and animal communities living in the soil and on its surface. Wetlands are found from the tundra to the tropics and on every continent except Antarctica. Wetlands are areas that are inundated or saturated by surface or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions. Wetlands generally include swamps, marshes, bogs and similar areas. Wetlands may be forested or unforested, and naturally or artificially created.

attr.attrdef: The 2 digit Hydrologic Unit Code for major river basins. Leading zeroes are not shown.

A unique identifier for the 'reach' of the stream. ?The first eight digits are the Watershed Boundary Dataset 8-digit Hydrologic Unit Code, which identifies the subbasin in which the stream is located. The next six digits are randomly assigned, sequential numbers that are unique within a subbasin, resulting in a 14-character value. ?This attribute links features back to the National Hydrography Dataset, National Hydrography Dataset Plus, and other data sets that use reach codes.
Length of the water body in meters
Online record of the water body
